measured_by: 9-point Likert scale (0 = not at all – 9 = very much)
justification: "Before and after the phase, a liking 9-point Likert scale ranging from 0 (not at all) to 9 (very much) was presented for each of the three CSs…" – indicating that subjective liking was operationalised with a 9-point Likert scale.

measured_by: 9-point Likert scale (0 = not at all – 9 = very much)
justification: "…new liking and wanting 9-point Likert scales, ranging from 0 (not at all) to 9 (very much), were presented for the two foods…" – showing that current wanting was assessed with the same 9-point scale.
"Participants were also asked to rate their current level of hunger, to ensure high hunger in all participants." – a self-report rating served as the measure of hunger.

"To test this hypothesis, we adopted a modified version of the Pavlovian-to-Instrumental Transfer (PIT) paradigm designed to assess optimal decision-making strategies." – the PIT paradigm is used to quantify how Pavlovian cues bias instrumental choices.

measured_by: Percentage of R1 vs. R2 choices in the instrumental learning phase of the PIT task
justification: "The acquisition of instrumental learning consisted of… increasing the percentage of R1 as compared to R2 in order to reach the reward matching." – the proportion of R1/R2 selections operationalises adherence to the optimal decision strategy.
